ImageData.LabelName: Cancer inside both ovaries or fallopian tubes
Cancer cells in pelvic peritoneal fluid

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: In the inset of the Stage IC panel, made the cancer cells as single floating cells in the pelvic peritoneum rather showing a tumor mass, and updated the label to say “Cancer cells in pelvic peritoneal fluid” - changes made per expert reviewer
In the Stage IC panel, accentuated the rupturing of the cells in label a and showed the tumor growing out toward the surface a bit more so that it is accentuated in label b.
In third panel, changed label from “…in peritoneal cavity” to “Cancer cells in pelvic peritoneum”

REVISED IMAGE per FIGO update: Removed "ovarian cancer" from title; In the middle and last panel, added a label for Fallopian tube; in the middle panel, changed label to say “Cancer inside both ovaries or fallopian tubes"; in the last panel, changed label to say “Cancer cells in peritoneal cavity”
Spacing of Fallopian tube label corrected.

Diagnoses.Diagnosis: stage I ovarian germ cell tumor

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Three-panel drawing of stage IA, stage IB, and stage IC; each panel shows the ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and vagina. The first panel (stage IA) shows cancer inside one ovary. The second panel (stage IB) shows cancer inside both ovaries. The third panel (stage IC) shows cancer inside both ovaries and (a) the tumor in the ovary on the left has ruptured (broken open), (b) there is cancer on the surface of the ovary on the right, and (c) there are cancer cells in the pelvic peritoneal fluid (inset).

Three-panel drawing of stage IA, stage IB, and stage IC; each panel shows the ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and vagina. The first panel (stage IA) shows cancer inside one ovary. The second panel (stage IB) shows cancer inside both ovaries. The third panel (stage IC) shows cancer inside both ovaries and (a) the tumor in the ovary shown on the left has ruptured (broken open), (b) there is cancer on the surface of the ovary shown on the right, and (c) there are cancer cells in the pelvic peritoneal fluid (inset).

Captions.MediaCaption: In stage IA, cancer is found inside a single ovary or fallopian tube. In stage IB, cancer is found inside both ovaries or fallopian tubes. In stage IC, cancer is found inside one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and one of the following is true: (a) either the tumor or the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary has ruptured (broken open), or (b) cancer is also found on the surface of the ovary or fallopian tube, or (c) cancer cells are found in the pelvic peritoneal fluid.

In stage IA, cancer is found inside a single ovary or fallopian tube. In stage IB, cancer is found inside both ovaries or fallopian tubes. In stage IC, cancer is found inside one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and one of the following is true: (a) either the tumor or the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary has ruptured (broken open), or (b) cancer is also found on the surface of the ovary or fallopian tube, or (c) cancer cells are found in the pelvic peritoneal fluid.

ProposedUse.Summary: Ovarian Epithelial, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Treatment
ProposedUse.Glossary: stage I ovarian epithelial and fallopian tube cancer
stage I ovarian germ cell tumor

ProcessingStatus.ProcessingStatusValue: Approved by expert reviewer with changes
ProcessingStatus.Comment: Recommended revising Stage IC panel to show free floating cancer cells in the pelvic peritoneum rather than showing what looks like a metastatic tumor in the peritoneum
Sent to Larissa Meyer, MD, MPH
